required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.official_title: Effects of Pre-emptive Use of Combined Ibuprofen and Acetaminophen on Pain Control in Orthodontic Treatment

brief_summary.textblock: This study is designed to determine if the preemptive use of a combination of acetaminophen and ibuprofen is more effective in reducing pain following orthodontic tooth movement when compared to the use of acetaminophen and ibuprofen alone. Before their orthodontic appointment, participants will be administered acetaminophen (650mg), ibuprofen (400mg), or acetaminophen (650mg) + ibuprofen (400mg). Participants will be asked to record their pain intensity using a numerical (0-10) visual analog scale (VAS) during rest, light biting, and while chewing paraffin wax during the following time intervals: immediately following drug administration, 6 hours after, the morning after, and the second morning after orthodontic treatment.

study_design_info.intervention_model_description: Patients of the University of Washington Graduate Orthodontics Clinic
study_design_info.masking_description: The medications were prepared by the Kelley-Ross Compounding Group (Seattle, WA) and were identical in appearance. The bottles were labeled as "A", "B", or "C" and the identity of the medications were not revealed until after the data analysis was completed.

primary_outcome.description: Pain scores were measured and recorded by selecting a number [0-10] using a visual analog scale to assess pain during each of the following: at rest, lightly biting, and chewing paraffin wax. The VAS consisted of a 10cm numerical scale from 0, representing "no pain," to 10, representing "worst possible, unbearable, excruciating pain."

Pain scores were measured and recorded by selecting a number [0-10] using a visual analog scale to assess pain during each of the following: at rest, lightly biting, and chewing paraffin wax. The VAS consisted of a 10cm numerical scale from 0, representing "no pain," to 10, representing "worst possible, unbearable, excruciating pain."

Pain scores were measured and recorded by selecting a number [0-10] using a visual analog scale to assess pain during each of the following: at rest, lightly biting, and chewing paraffin wax. The VAS consisted of a 10cm numerical scale from 0, representing "no pain," to 10, representing "worst possible, unbearable, excruciating pain."

arm_group.description: Acetaminophen 650mg powder in gel capsule taken by mouth before entering appointment
Ibuprofen 400mg powder in gel capsule taken by mouth before entering appointment
Acetaminophen 650mg and Ibuprofen 400mg powder in gel capsule taken by mouth before entering appointment

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
-Orthodontic patient presenting for orthodontic treatment
Exclusion Criteria:
- History of taking an analgesic in the past six hours
- Hypersensitivity to ibuprofen or acetaminophen
- Aspirin-sensitive asthma
- Renal or liver impairment
- History of GI bleeding or ulcers
- Cardiovascular disease, recent myocardial infarction, heart failure, or coronary artery bypass graft surgery
- Currently taking antibiotics or other medications for a chronic systemic disease
- Bleeding disorder
- Pregnant or nursing
